perturbation.original_text:
In the event that eDiets fails, within five (5) days
after submission by Women.com, to provide Women.com with necessary revisions
thereto, such failure shall be deemed to be approval of Women.com's edits.
perturbation.changed_text:
In the event that eDiets fails, within two (2) days
after submission by Women.com, to provide Women.com with necessary revisions
thereto, such failure shall be deemed to be approval of Women.com's edits.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the revision period to two days could be unreasonably short, potentially violating good faith and fair dealing principles, especially if the revisions require substantial effort or expertise. This abbreviated timeframe may not allow eDiets adequate opportunity to review and respond, potentially leading to unfavorable terms being imposed upon them. Many states require reasonable timeframes for contractual obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, contract law principles related to reasonable notice and opportunity to cure.

perturbation.original_text:
Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the
Women.com Marks upon seventy-two (72) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon
expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of
the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.changed_text:
Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the
Women.com Marks upon twenty-four (24) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon
expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of
the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for trademark usage withdrawal to 24 hours is too short notice for eDiets. Such actions could be viewed as a breach of good faith as insufficient time to adjust marketing materials could cause considerable disruption. Standards usually expect a reasonable amount of time.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of good faith, Trademark Usage Law

perturbation.original_text:
Within fifteen (15) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a
written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential
Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies
thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to
Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's
instruction. Receiving Party shall then certify the same in writing and that no
copies have been retained by Receiving Party, its employees, agents or
contractors.
perturbation.changed_text:
Within five (5) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a
written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential
Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies
thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to
Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's
instruction. Receiving Party shall then certify the same in writing and that no
copies have been retained by Receiving Party, its employees, agents or
contractors.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the timeframe to return or destroy confidential information to 5 days, may be seen as non-compliant. This timeframe may be insufficient for complex information systems. This creates risk of not properly disposing the information, in violation of data privacy laws.
